news.title: Amazon Research Award
news.description: We're building the AutoML Gym, an online environment for training and testing Automatic Machine Learning systems

news.title: Tutorial Speaker @ NeurIPS 2018
news.description: Amazing experience giving a NeurIPS tutorial on AutoML and Meta-learning in front of 2000+ people! Together with Frank Hutter. Video and slides below!

news.title: OpenML mentioned in Science Magazine
news.description: Nice article about the difficulty of reproducibility and how OpenAI Gym and OpenML are taking steps in the right direction.

news.title: Dutch Science Foundation Grant
news.description: We will explore Dynamic Data Analytics through automatically Constructed Machine Learning Pipelines. Bilge Celik is taking on the challenge.

news.title: DARPA Grant
news.description: The (civilian) Data-Driven Discovery of Models project develops open-source tools to automate machine learning on any type of data. Pieter Gijsbers is starting his PhD on this topic.

news.title: OpenML won the Dutch Data Prize
news.description: Thanks so much to the organizers for stimulating open science through this award, and thanks to the fantastic OpenML team for making it all happen!

news.title: HARVEST Grant from the PASCAL 2 Network
news.description: The funding received will support work on OpenML, a new system to automatically share and reuse reproducible machine learning experiments.

news.title: Free Competition Research Grant (NWO)
news.description: The funding received will support work on Massively Collaborative Data Mining. Jan N. van Rijn will start his PhD on this topic.

news.title: Best Demo Award @ ECMLPKDD 2009
news.description: For a demonstration of Experiment Databases for machine learning. Together with Hendrik Blockeel.

invited.title: NeurIPS 2018 Open-source Machine Learning Workshop
invited.description: On OpenML and building open source communities for machine learning. Thanks to Sergey, Victor, Cheng, Heiko, Ryan, and Antti!

invited.title: PRICAI 2018 AutoML Workshop
invited.description: On how to do automatic machine learning with OpenML. Thanks to Isabelle Guyon, Hugo, Wei-wei, Zhanxing, and Yang.

invited.title: SIGMOD 2018 DEEM Workshop
invited.description: On the use of OpenML in Data Management for End-to-End Machine Learning. Special thanks to Sebastian Schelter.

invited.title: Dutch National eScience Symposium
invited.description: I'm speaking in the 'Future of machine learning' track. Thanks to everyone at the eScience Center!

invited.title: ICML 2017 - Reproducibility in Machine Learning Workshop
invited.description: Very lively workshop on reproducibility - a crucial aspect of machine learning research. Thanks so much to Sami Bengio, Anirudh Goyal, and the other organizers for the great discussions.

invited.title: NIPS 2016 - Challenges in Machine Learning Workshop
invited.description: On using OpenML for running open, collaborative machine learning challenges. Thanks to Isabelle Guyon and the other organizers.

invited.title: Dutch Society for Pattern Recognition
invited.description: On the use of OpenML for machine learning on medical data. Thanks to Veronika Cheplygina for inviting me!

invited.title: Data@Sheffield
invited.description: A tutorial on OpenML targetted at scientists from many domains, at the Open Data Science @ Sheffield workshop and Data Hide event. Many, many thanks to Neil Lawrence and the Open Data Science Initiative for a splendid visit and engaging discussions.

invited.title: IDA 2015 (Horizon Talk)
invited.description: In this Horizon talk, I proposed the idea of a data science collaboratory, where scientists across domains can collaborate effortlessly using each other's data and code. Joint work with Bernd Bischl, Frank Hutter, Michele Sebag, Balazs Kegl, Matthias Schmid, Giulio Napolitano, Katy Wolstencroft, Alan R. Williams, and Neil Lawrence.

invited.title: Statistical Computing 2015
invited.description: On networked science, OpenML and using OpenML from statistical environments such as R. Followed by a hands-on tutorial by Giuseppe Casalicchio and Bernd Bischl. Thanks to Matthias Schmid.

invited.title: ICML 2015 AutoML Workshop
invited.description: On OpenML and building systems that learn from machine learning experiments, to assist people while analyzing data, or automate the process altogether. Thanks to Balazs Kegl and Frank Hutter.

invited.title: ECDA 2014
invited.description: On open science, machine learning, OpenML and the benefits it brings for machine learning research, individual scientists, as well as students and practitioners.

invited.title: CLADAG 2013
invited.description: Presenting the first beta version of OpenML. Thanks to John Shawe-Taylor and the PASCAL 2 Network.

talks.title: Learning how to learn
talks.description: On the state of the art and future of meta-learning (Berlin ML Meetup 2019)

talks.title: Tutorial on Automatic Machine Learning
talks.description: Presented at NeurIPS 2018 by Frank Hutter and myself.

talks.title: Introduction to OpenML
talks.description: How OpenML works, how to use it, and the people behind it all. (NeurIPS 2018)

talks.title: Interview Open Science Radio (podcast)
talks.description: Open discussion on open science in machine learning. With Heidi Seibold.

talks.title: Collaborative Machine Learning
talks.description: On collaborative platforms for scientists and machine learning experts.

talks.title: OpenML: Networked Science in Machine Learning
talks.description: On the open science principles underlying OpenML.

talks.title: Designed Serendipity
talks.description: Short talk on designed serendipity in science (inspired by M. Nielsen).

talks.title: Exposé
talks.description: Explains the Exposé ontology for machine learning experiments

books.title: Automatic Machine Learning
books.subtitle: Methods, systems, challenges
books.description: Tutorial-level overview of the methods underlying automatic machine learning, enabling readers to easily understand the key concepts behind AutoML. It contains extensive surveys of hyperparameter tuning, meta-learning, and neural architecture search, as well detailed descriptions of modern AutoML systems.

open.name: PostDoc
open.topic: The AutoML Gym: an online environment for training AutoML systems

open.name: PhD
open.topic: Fast deep learning by slow meta-learning

industry.title: Deep reinforcement learning for bin packing (Vanderlande)
industry.description: Bin packing is a challenging optimization problem that thus far has not yet been addressed by reinforcement learning. You need to set up a simulation environment in OpenAI Gym and develop new reinforcement learning algorithms to solve it.

industry.title: Machine learning for vertical farming (Philips)
industry.description: In vertical farming, plants are grown under ideal controlled conditions. Machine learning is needed to track plant growth and define the optimal conditions. Possible techniques are reinforment learning, deep meta-learning, or recurrent neural nets.

industry.title: Machine learning on temporal location data (Philips)
Embedded deep learning (Philips)
industry.description: Deep learning models are often hard to embed into low-power devices because they consume too much memory of compute. Techniques such as low precision neural networks or sparse neural networks can be used to address this. Your challenge is to use these in specific applications.

academic.title: Automated data cleaning
academic.description: Datasets usually require a lot of manual cleaning before it can be used for machine learning. Your challenge is to develop tools that automate this process as much as possible. They will be tested on large amounts of structured and unstructured datasets. This problem can be subdivided into several subproblems, such as data parsing, cleansing, outlier detection,... depending on your own interests.

academic.title: Meta-learning for automated data preprocessing
academic.description: Data preprocessing is a general term for all operations that have to be done before training a predictive model. Current techniques to automate this often focus on defining experimentally what's best for the given data. However, as humans we build an understanding of what generally works (or not) on certain types of data. Your challenge is to build meta-models or meta-learning systems that learn across tasks to more intelligently choose which preprocessing techniques to try on a given dataset.

academic.title: Active Meta-learning
academic.description: In meta-learning, we build models about the behavior of learning algorithms, so that we can predict which algorithms (or neural architectures) to use for specific problems. It is often expensive to gather training data for these models (each data point requires fully training a new model). Your challenge is to use active learning to only experiment with those models that we can learn most from. This is a necessary step towards building efficient meta-learning systems.

academic.title: Model-agnostic meta-learning for automated machine learning
academic.description: Model-agnostic meta-learning learns an optimal parameter initialization for a set of related tasks. We want to explore whether this also works for designing machine learning pipelines: how can we learn optimal initialized pipelines and how can we adapt them quickly to the data at hand.

academic.title: Multi-fidelity meta-learning
academic.description: Multi-fidelity optimization techniques compute cheap estimates of the measure they want to optimize (e.g. train a model on a small subset of data to get an estimate of performance on the entire dataset). These estimates are then used to select a subset of options to be evaluated more in depth in the next iteration. Currently, these techniques don't use any machine learning. Your challenge is to see whether we can do meta-learning between iterations to more effectively decide which options to evaluate in the next iteration.

academic.title: A Tensorflow binding for OpenML
academic.description: OpenML is a platform for sharing machine learning models, and already has bindings for many Python libraries, such as scikit-learn and Keras. Recent improvements in TensorFlow make it interesting to share TensorFlow pipelines on OpenML as well. This work combines engineering with deep knowledge of machine learning models and systems.

academic.title: Defense against overfitting
academic.description: There exist many approaches to avoid overfitting, such as early stopping, variance reduction, and reusable holdouts. They all have their benefits and drawbacks but there doesn't exists a lot of work on choosing between them. It is often an art rather than a science. Your challenge is to study this problem in depth and to recommend the best approaches for different scenarios.

academic.title: Frugal learning
academic.description: Imagine that you want to develop a smartwatch app that does machine learning for a privacy-sensitive application (e.g. health tracking). It is often impossible to collect large amounts of data, nor are there large related datasets, e.g. because of privacy concerns. This severely limits your options about which algorithms to use. Your goal is to develop intelligent metrics and methods for building models under these conditions. You can also test them in smart watches.
